awd_titl_txt: Dynamics and Control of Tethered Multi-Rotor Unmanned Aerial Vehicles with Switchable Powered and Autorotation Modes
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will promote the progress of dynamic modeling and control design, and advance the national prosperity, welfare and security by increasing both the time aloft and the energy efficiency of tethered unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), which are used for surveillance, communication, and sensing. The use of tethered UAVs deserves attention since they can provide a compact, portable, temporary, and rapidly deployable alternative to helicopters or satellites. The presented system, powered through an electrically conductive tether, can increase the time UAVs can remain in the air and reduce the weight of on-board batteries. The project will study the use of suitable blade geometry, a flapping/teetering degree of freedom, and active feedback control with the goal to enhance energy efficiency of a UAV by switching to autorotation when prevailing wind speeds are high. Accordingly, the new design will have the capability of reducing its energy requirement by harnessing wind energy while in operation. The system will be portable, easily deployable, and actively controlled. It will be agile, maneuverable, and its ability to switch between two flight modes will allow robust hovering at desired altitudes and orientations. The project will leverage University of Central Florida iSTEM program to involve women and underrepresented minority students in research activities and enable community outreach via the Orlando Science Center. The project will foster ongoing collaborative research with the energy and power industry and create new collaboration with local industry partners that have business interest in tethered UAVs.

The research will make fundamental advances in operation of tethered UAVs by undertaking extensive efforts in dynamic modeling and control design. The two flight modes, their unique set of actuations and inputs, and the distinct aerodynamic characteristics of autorotation, distinguish the control of the system from conventional multi-rotor systems. The system has a Multi-Input Multi-Output structure, alternating causalities, many disturbance sources, a wide array of parameters, and requires active control for delivering the functionalities. The system admits a continuum of equilibria. This research will determine the feasible and optimal subspaces within this equilibrium space where, (1) the momentum theory holds and gives an accurate prediction of the aerodynamics, (2) sufficient lift is generated, and (3) the tether tension is confined within acceptable limits. Stabilization of the system will take fundamentally new directions, involving switched control, uncertainty quantification, and feed-forward actions. During autorotation, differential regenerative braking will be employed for attitude stabilization. Robust autorotation will be achieved by tether length actuation and intermittent mode switching. Thereby energy efficiency and active attitude/altitude control will become integrally coupled. The geometric symmetry of the structure will facilitate control design using reduced-order models while incurring minimal loss of generality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award investigates the physics of autorotation in the context of tethered multi-rotor autogyros, where each rotor can switch between conventional powered mode and autorotation mode. In autorotation, a rotor is not powered but uses the prevailing wind field to generate enough lift force to support its weight. This application of autorotation makes energy efficient tethered UAVs feasible, where the application could be surveillance or communications while being stationed or flying in a limited space. The tether in this case can be used not only for mooring but also to transfer electrical power bidirectionally, thus enabling powering the rotors when wind is not conducive to autorotation and thereby prolonging flight time. In addition, the concept opens possibilities of airborne wind energy generation when deployed at high enough altitudes where the wind power is high and persistent. Starting from the seminal works, which were focused on helicopters, this research extends the physics of autorotation to the proposed application scenario through some critical modifications, such as incorporation of regenerative braking torques. During autorotation, regenerative braking offers a novel on-board control authority to the multi-rotor system that not only provides actuation torques but can also be used to generate power. Specifically, differential regenerative braking among the different rotors is proposed for modulating the system’s position and attitude. In addition, tether length actuation provides another control input.

The approach of this research is model based. The basic autorotation model uses the Blade-Element-Momentum approach. It is validated against both simulation and experimental data reported by some of the earliest works on autorotation. The overall system model builds on this basic model by adding features such as multi-body dynamics, tether dynamics, regenerative braking, etc. The model is used to characterize the system. It is shown that the tethered system has multiple equilibria at different altitudes and pitch inclinations. An important observation from the characterization study is that an optimal tip-speed-ratio of about 0.2 exists where the system achieves high elevation to drift ratio and is a good operating condition to target in flight. It is also evident that the nature of the equilibria ranges from lift-dominated to drag-dominated regimes, with the former best suited for flight conditions and coinciding with the aforementioned optimal tip-speed-ratio.

Controls and performance study of this system is conducted using both an averaged dynamic model as well as detailed first principles based dynamic model. The former is a simpler model and hence allows the testing of fundamental control actions and their effects. The latter helps in the fine-tuning of control algorithms. The former is also helpful in analyzing stability of the system under different closed-loop controls. The research has achieved altitude control of the multi-rotor system using a combination of system pitch control and tether length actuation. Pitch control enables fine control of altitude whereas tether length actuation is used for course altitude changes. A nested loop control structure is found to be well-suited to handle the nonlinearities of the system. The nesting consists of an outer altitude control loop and an inner pitch/tether-length control loop. Actuations are still the regenerative braking torques applied at each rotor. The ability to switch between autorotation and powered flight is also verified. Specifically, the same control algorithm can switch to powered mode, i.e., apply accelerating torques at rotors, when wind speeds drop. This satisfies one of the basic premises of this research of switchable flight-modes being the enabler of sustained flight for the proposed system under uncertain wind conditions.

A companion investigation, conducted as part of this research, is on the nature of autorotation in samaras which are produced by maple trees. Samaras are single wing seed-pods that maple trees have evolved to produce, for the purposes of dispersion of seeds. Their natural aerodynamic shapes allow them to gracefully autorotate as they descend from the trees and prevailing winds can cause them to disperse. In this research, the autorotation of various maple samaras was experimentally and analytically studied. Various operating parameters such as speed of descent, rotational speed, pitch angle, etc. were recorded. An aerodynamic model was formulated using fundamental rigid body assumptions and airfoil theory. The model was validated against experimental data and verified against results reported in the literature. A rigorous stability analysis of the autorotation phenomenon was conducted using the model and stability conditions were derived. Please see https://youtu.be/B9Bl_dBsOIo for a video of the autorotating samara.

Please refer to published papers by the PI and his students on this research.
